posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked: The text is about exploring motion control strategies, particularly focusing on feedback-based control loops such as PID control. It discusses implementing these loops on different types of motor controllers, like swerve drives versus elevators, arms, or linear motion systems. The conversation also touches on whether to use code running on the RoboRIO or leverage existing motor controller features for managing these loops, and considers past experiences with on-controller vs off-controller approaches. The broader aim is to gather insights from the community to inform decisions about motor ecosystem development.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked: This year, on my request, all motors doing position or velocity control were required to use CTRE, Cross The Road Electronics. Our offseason experience with Motion Magic was significantly better than Smart Motion. We preferred running control loops on the motor because it is faster and avoids overshoots caused by loop overruns. CTRE's fused absolute encoder mode performed exceptionally well on our pivot mechanism and was straightforward to set up. In my opinion, Phoenix Tuner offers a more user-friendly experience compared to the Rev Hardware Client. If you're considering a switch, I recommend it, though it wouldn't magically enhance your performance; we could have achieved similar results using Rev motors instead. The overall experience was notably improved with CTRE.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
The text has been cleaned up to remove unnecessary words and improve clarity while maintaining its original meaning. Here is the revised version:

Importantlyn, we plan the setpointss on theRioand utilize theoutboardcontroller forfeedback, employing thebuilt-inencoders. I no longer feel the samewaymy mentor doesthatoutboardcontrol isn’t as effective a teaching tool. However, using simplePID onanintegratedsensor remains straightforward, and you aren’t significantly disadvantaged by shifting it. We still avoid using motionmagic or similar techniques because they are challenging to utilize effectively.

We prefer to maintain simplicity at theoutboardlayerbecause we aim to handlemultipleaxeswithour advanced system. Consequently,alltrajectory or profilework must occuron theRiousing workspacecoordinates; themotorcontrollers cannot assist in this process.

If you're using CTR modules, there’s no debate about choosing their onboard control over the roborio—it offers full feedforward support (kS, kV, kA, kG) with both cosine gravity feedforward for arms and static gravity feedforward for elevators. It operates at 1 kHz with low latency, ensuring smooth control and aggressive tuning capabilities. The Motion Magic control simplifies motion profiling with trapezoidal or exponential profiles and is straightforward to set up. Additionally, you can tune PID, FF, and motion constraints on the spot with no code needed using Phoenix Tuner X. FusedCANNoder is equally impressive, functioning almost magically. For swerve applications, the CTR swerve library proves highly effective, replicating the same control inputs beneath the hood. As for REV systems, I’m unsure and find them unhelpful; hopefully, their library will improve soon.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: For both the swerve drive and other manipulators, we are using the CTRE Cross The Road Electronics FOC Field Oriented Control motor controller, but we apply different feedforward control methods depending on the mechanism. For the swerve, we used the default CTRE feedforward controller, which uses the constants Ks, Kv, and Ka. For our elevator and arm, we employ a custom feedforward algorithm that runs on the RoboRIO, along with a custom profile controller and CTRE motion magic FOC. This custom algorithm enables us to perform more complex calculations, such as how the motion of one subsystem affects the feedforward value of another.

The motion profiles are on the Rio and handle position and velocity setpoints via motor controllers. Maxmotion didn’t work for us. Non-motion-profiled subsystems use PID on the Spark to simplify coding. For swerve turning, PID is applied to the RIo because it’s easier to connect absolute encoders compared to the Spark, which needs a breakout board. We don’t use feedforward on driving motors, potentially affecting path following.

posts.name: Eugene Fang
posts.cooked:
outboard control isn’t as good a teacher  
it’s hard to learn anything from it  

hot take: teaching/learning is for the offseason. in season you should be using whatever is the easiest and most performant (which most of the time is outboard control w/ motionmagic), and students should understand how they work under the hood from good off season preparation. of course there are cases where you can’t and need to fall back to on- rio control.  

with how fast modern mechanisms move, it’s much safer to do outboard control so any rio loop overruns don’t destroy your mechanism.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: CTRE motion magic is now used for all PID loops. Try it out and adjust acceleration and cruise velocity. Put your PIDs directly on the controller for faster and easier tuning. Phoenix tuner is your friend.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: I just had a conversation with my programming mentor about why we’re not using the offboard controls today. While it’s good to learn the fundamentals when the time is right, especially when students aren’t struggling with complex problems, it’s more rewarding to see something work and then dig deeper underneath the hood.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: heh, well, that’s too spicy for me. I think getting into the details, under pressure, is sort of the whole point. but I don’t mean to imply that what we do is best for everyone. it’s just what we do.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked:
EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. The text is:

Important to note that you don’t have to fully switch ecosystems to get these benefits, buying all new motors is really expensive, especially when you may only have one or two mechanisms that you would want nicer software for. In that case you might want to check out the talon FXS, which should have the same software features of other CTRE devices, but it works with non-CTRE 3rd party motors.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Opinion: feed forward matters more than feedback for FRC scale high-performance systems. I don’t personally give two farts about what features vendors toss into their boxes. They’re nice and all, but I value a low-latency voltage control or current control far more than full in-motor motion control. I know how my robot works, the motor doesn’t. That’s not to say these things don’t have some usage. But if you’re looking for top performance, you need something customizable - not canned.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked:
That’s not to say these things don’t have some usage. But if you’re looking for top performance, you need something customizable—not canned.  

I think I disagree on this. Look through the codebases of some of the top teams. A lot of them are running Motion Magic with the CTRE provided feedforward. For really complex systems with multiple degrees of freedom and nonlinear behavior, more custom control can make sense. It worked well for teams like 6328 and 6036 in 2023, who did some advanced modeling with CasADi, but such complexity is rare. Most high-level teams hit elite performance without that level of complexity. Canned doesn’t mean low performance. It’s all about how you use the tools. A simple control scheme that works lets you spend time on things that actually improve your performance, instead of chasing 1 percent improvements that probably don’t matter in a match.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked: Honestly, 1323 robots have utilized most of the CTR out-of-the-box features. The product is excellent and I can’t recommend it enough. CTR itself has been amazing for us, particularly in handling high-performance tasks.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I’m not convinced there’s a significant performance difference between performing your profiles/feedforwards on the RIO versus the controller, apart from a reduction in CAN controller network traffic.

You should definitely run feedback on the controller rather than the RIO when using modern motors.

There’s no compelling reason in most cases not to utilize motion magic now that it supports all the standard WPILib feedforward terms, which means we shouldn’t be surprised to see top teams employing it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
if you’re looking for top performance, you need something customizable—not canned. fwew, 6328 has generally found an appropriate balance here by running pure feedback on motor controllers with everything else—feedforward, profiles, etc—implemented on the rio. we’ve never used motion magic or ctre’s on-controller feedforward in competition—even after switching to their ecosystem on our primary robots in 2024.  

this approach has worked exceptionally well for us because it takes advantage of how each platform works best: feedback controllers benefit from a faster update rate, but profiles and feedforward benefit from higher levels of customization—especially useful when we’re frequently dealing with complex transitions between control modes or alternative ff/profile models that would be difficult or impossible to implement with vendor libraries. we’ve never found any mechanism where running a feedforward or profile faster than 50hz makes a measurable performance difference, so there’s no point in making more work for ourselves by restricting our options unnecessarily. that applies to hardware too, since this approach means we aren’t locked to using ctre’s products on our development robot.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Have you had any problems with CAN bus overhead sending updates to every controller every 20ms? This is the only real performance reason I can think of to avoid RIO profiling.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: CAN utilization has never been a significant issue for us. In 2024 and 2025 we ran nearly every subsystem except the drive on the RIO bus, and in 2022 and 2023 we were using all REV hardware.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: In 2023 we used the RIO profile with RIO feedforward and Spark MAX PID Proportional Integral Derivative configured and encountered challenges with consistent 20ms RIO loop performance due to typical issues. This made setting up acceleration feedforwards particularly inconsistent because the prior loop time wasn’t a reliable metric.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
This has generally been our experience as well (abets, with good enough feed forward, the feedback often matters less).

To RC’s point, something I probably should have made clearer: Just because a team heavily leverages onboard features certainly doesn’t imply that their robot isn’t high performing from a points perspective, nor that their mechanisms aren’t high performing from a controls perspective. My opinion (definitely not theory) is only that pure onboard control logic will eventually be outperformed by custom-designed feed forward… but whether that tipping point is before or after the “turn L’s into W’s” point is very questionable to me.

This is exactly the gain set I would have hoped for for a feedforward model that covers 99.9% of FIRST Robotics Competition situations.
